O filme acontece em uma sociedade inglesa distópica, que após enfrentar uma guerra contra os Estados Unidos, sucumbe ao regime do ditador Sutler. Ele se aproveita de toda a crise para ganhar as eleições e se utiliza de leis totalitárias, censura generalizada da mídia e tortura dos opositores para se manter no poder. Dessa forma, não há nenhuma liberdade em seu regime autoritário, tudo passa por um filtro antes de ser publicado e todos estão alienados ou conformados com essa situação, visto que por medo da guerra, a população prefere trocar a liberdade por uma falsa sensação de segurança.

Sendo assim, o governo retira qualquer indesejado que esteja contra a ideia hegemônica do ditador, sejam eles homossexuais, negros, muçulmanos e outras minorias. Nesse contexto, surge o protagonista V, que basicamente é a personificação do sentimento de liberdade, mas sob um tom terrorista e anarquista, ao menos na perspectiva do governo, pois pela ótica dos cidadãos ele é um herói ou alguém que leva esperança. Para isso V pretende chamar a atenção do povo em relação ao que o Estado está fazendo, no entanto, faz isso através do medo, assim, essa será uma das poucas vezes que nos encontraremos torcendo para um "terrorista".

Em virtude disso, essa é uma história com questões delicadas que vão lhe fazer refletir sobre qual o preço da liberdade, o que estamos dispostos a pagar por ela e nos faz extravasar o sentimento de insignificância ao sermos controlados pelo governo, nesse caso totalitário, uma vez que é ele que deve temer o seu povo e não contrário. Logo, mesmo com um roteiro mais minimalista, sem muita ação, temos com uma boa fotografia e uma excelente discussão temática, tonando a obra deslumbrante, principalmente para quem gosta de filosofia e sociologia.

Contudo, o filme não chega a ser genial, pois ainda que seja bem envolvente temos muitas passagens entediante, um vilão que é caricato e pouco relevante, tanto que quase não tem aparições. Dessa maneira, várias das cenas que não contém o protagonista se tornam fracas, em exceção a investigação feita pelo detetive Finch, no qual, nos empolgamos com o mistério a ser resolvido e a "libertação" da personagem Evey, quando ela está presa. Portanto, V de Vingança é uma obra de fácil digestão, já que não foca em diversas outras questões que poderiam ser aprofundadas e se retém ao tema da liberdade, criando, brilhantemente, sua marca nesse aspecto.

This film review will be about "V for Vendetta," and a spoiler of the movie can be seen in this review. "V for Vendetta" is a movie taken from a book by Alan Moore, written years ago before wars and government problems were initiated. This movie begins when experimenting, and everything goes wrong, killing innocent people to get to the point they wanted to be and creating a government that assures keeping people safe, but not freedom. Finally, one guy finds a way to escape and returns for revenge. He always says to remember the day, the 5th of November, because he wanted to make people get united and fight against the government. Also, as he said, "people should not be afraid of their government. Governments should be afraid of their people." In his journey, he finds a girl; to me, she was his redemption at some point because her love reminded him that he was loved. He had something more to fight about but also feared who he was. The mask and Valerie are the two main elements of this story because Valerie is the reminder and the power to fight, and the mask represents himself and the people he is fighting for.

This movie was a window for the future; now, we can see that political violence is happening and that, like the movie, many people thought that the government sent the covid. Now we know a virus hit our world, causing so many deaths, probably without reason; that's what many think, right? So, this movie is about power and politics. It can be from the power of love, people, a change of life, an act of killing, and then the turning of a page. It can be fascinating how the system can bring us all together to challenge an ideal or power and that if we come together to fight for the same goal, we can indeed change the world, being possible to create new realities, but, of course, we can do things in a non-violent way. The significant purpose or message that this movie has is that we must come together as people to challenge power, which is true because a mass of people fighting for the same objective can be more powerful than a government, for example. Additionally, how the power of people and love united can win, no matter the reason you are fighting for, in the end, it will succeed.

In conclusion, this is a great movie, and there are so many learning experiences that everybody can get from this movie, but this movie should be seen by adult audiences or parental guidance because there are some sensitive scenes. Critiquing this movie can be complicated and tricky because the topics that this movie talks about are very challenging and powerful topics to talk about during these days. Also, in the end, this movie answers any questions that, as the audience, we can have, is not the typical ending that everybody expects. Still, it is a great movie that shows how the power of incorrect people can cause so much danger, but the hope and unity of a group can win any situation.

The movie V for Vendetta is a mysterious, action-packed movie set in England in 2020. However, this is not the England people think of today; in this movie, the British government has become oppressive and taken away many freedoms of its citizens. Throughout this mysterious movie, horrific details begin to reveal about the British government. The main character, a guy by the name of V, does all he can to reveal the truth and seek revenge. After V stumbles upon a young British woman by the name of Evie, the two more or less team up to avenge the British government; the more the movie progresses, the more secrets are revealed, and the more questions are asked. The movie's biggest question is, who is V? Why does V seek vengeance on the government? Not every question can be answered in this movie, but it will definitely leave you with a better understanding of who V is and how the government has affected his life. 
     Critiquing this movie on its originality is tricky because there are countless movies out there about an oppressive government becoming too powerful and keeping secrets from its citizens. However, this movie shows its uniqueness by having the character V. This critique also goes into how well the characters were portrayed in the movie. V is a mysterious character who can come off as creepy, weird, or even evil. His character was so original it was hard to decipher how to feel about him until the very end because, at different points in the movie, you could not see his true intentions. There are many twists throughout this movie which also helps contribute to its originality. However, one unoriginal or predictable aspect was V's feelings for Evie. It followed the "bad guy falls for sweet innocent girl" plot but in a very subtle way.
     Another criterion to evaluate is the dialogue in this movie. The dialogue throughout this movie can sometimes come off as confusing, especially when V is introduced; he even confuses Evie. For example, at the beginning of the film, he follows a rhyme scheme making him sound poetic, which just came off as confusing at first. However, as the movie progressed, and V's personality was easier to understand, so was his dialogue. V and Evie's personality traits are expressed through their dialogue. Evie comes across as a sweet innocent, ordinary girl, while V comes across as a harsh and heartless man.
     The movie does a great job answering the audience's questions while still keeping them on their toes. It is an excellent movie for anyone who loves action and fighting scenes. It is not your typical happy-go-lucky movie, and the end will throw you for a loop. Overall, this movie has many unique and memorable aspects shown through the characters, their dialogue, and the story plot that you will not find anywhere else.

The use of strong imagery and the way the characters perform and develop in V for Vendetta make the film come together as a way for it to be entertaining for the people who are watching. I will talk about some things that happen in the movie so I am putting a spoiler alert. At the beginning of the film, we get introduced to the main character, a masked man who goes by the name V. The mask that V is seen with throughout the film is to hide his identity, but the mask also has a permanent smile on it. The smile on the mask could be a way for there to be a more creepy tone to the film. Many other things may add to the film's tone, but another one is that most of the scenes in the movie are shot in very dark lighting. V is very mysterious and lives in England under a government that many may see as a dictatorship. Towards the beginning of the film, V is seen as he is going to be the villain of the film, but as the film progresses and things begin to unfold, one could say the government is the actual villain. People living in England obey the government out of fear, except V, who stands against them and says in one of his famous lines, "People shouldn't be afraid of their government. Governments should be afraid of their people"(V for Vendetta). V stands against his government as a form of revenge which he believes can be a form of symbolism. He believes that the chaotic and disastrous things he does will send a message to the people he is trying to reach. In this case, it's the government, and people will remember what he did and for what reasons. The character's performance and development improved how well the film was written. V was masked the entire film, but as the watchers, we still managed to see and feel his emotions. V also met a girl named Evey Hammond, whom he cared for and saved from being punished by their government. Evey could feel and understand V's emotions even with being masked the whole time because even though V never showed his identity, he was still vulnerable around Evey. Soon after, Evey and V began to bond and created what seemed like a romantic relationship between the two. With the government seeing V as a terrorist, many people disagreed with the government and began to follow V and support his ideas, including Evey. V for Vendetta is known as being an action film, but it carries a solid underlying meaning. The film can also be a way for us to relate to it because we've had protests and riots happen all around the United States to get the government to see us and make a change. Overall I think V for Vendetta was a good film with a relatable meaning that many people can relate to.

The film adaptation of V for Vendetta is a film full of impactful themes, a well thought out and constructed world, and several memorable characters, even if the characters that exist in this world can often be underutilized. This is done through broody and unforgiving settings that will leave viewers rooting for characters that in other films would be villains. Following the main character who is essentially a terrorist and having the viewer rooting for them by the end is something unique to this film 

 

To better understand the thoughts and motivations of characters it is first important to understand the world they inhabit. Set in an alternate history version of the United Kingdom, V for Vendetta sets out to create a dystopian fascist society for its events to take place within. While well done for the most part, scenes involving setting up the world can be a bit tacky. For example, a particular scene revolving around the assault of a key character comes across as tacky and unnecessary. However, this is the exception and not the rule as the scenes involving the fictional British news company and a shadow government do a great job to portray a heavy-handed fascist government. This is helped by giving the audience individual characters that act as the face of the evil government in the movie. 

 

The film follows two main protagonists, one who calls themselves "V" a vigilante whose motivations unknown to the viewer, seeks to change society in a violent revolution. The second protagonist being someone named "Evey" as they simply seek to survive in dystopian society. Both characters heavily carry the best moments of the movie, their interactions serving as key turning points throughout the entire film. V, whose identity is unknown is a mysterious figure whose multiple motivations will leave the viewer constantly questioning if this character is the one, they should be rooting for. 

 

Aside from the protagonists the film features several detailed characters that are a very mixed bag of quality. The main villains who are being ordered around on a massive television screen by the "High Chancellor" while sometimes coming across as mustache twirling, serve their purpose at driving the movie forward. However, this can be a bit draining as some characters seem to only exist to serve their main purpose in the plot, and then hastily written off. This happens in the form of very important characters in the movie never having their motivations properly explained. 

 

One of the most notable things about the movie is its well thought out themes. The most integral one is the theme of fear, and how that can be used to rule over a populace, and in the case of the movie a fascist government. This theme relates to multiple characters in the film as they seek in their own ways to overcome this fear, and to not let it rule the actions that they take. Many audience members will find this relatable, as fear deterring one from their proper path is something that many people can relate to. 

 

V for Vendetta is a solid film and while it can be a bit messy with its messaging at times, the sum of its parts is greater than the whole. Many viewers will have multiple messages in the film that they relate to, even if they are blown up to great proportions in the film. With a solid slew of characters, a world to get lost in, and resonating themes V for Vendetta is a film that most people will enjoy.

The movie for V for Vendetta is an insightful portrayal of the graphic novel version Alan Moore had illustrated. Both the graphic novel and movie are about the dystopian society in which the regime Norsefire control England. The story conveys the conflict between the oppression of fascism that the authority inflicts, and the desire for the citizens to rebel against the suffocation. 

In general, there are various differences between the graphic novel and the film depiction of V for Vendetta. For instance, during the beginning of the film, Evey was depicted as girl who was desperate to leave V, and had even confessed to the priest to save her. Following this, she chose to escape V and consequently met Gordon. In comparison, the graphic novel gave the impression that Evey was on V's side and supported him. This is because she had played along in a few of V's schemes and she didn't try to escape, on the contrary, V had told her to leave. In general, these subtle portrayals of Evey can have different impacts on the readers. For instance, by having her be on V's side from the beginning reflected that majority of the citizens are against the Norsefire and it also portrayed V through a heroic lens (ironically, despite the fact that he destroys and schemes). On the other hand, the other portrayal was a more realistic response to being in Evey's position, taking into consideration V's capabilities and murders. 

In addition, the resolution of the film concluded with all the citizens wearing V's masks. This is extremely different from the graphic novel, and it offers strong symbolic significance. The mask itself symbolizes the defiance against the government and the oppression they inflicted. The fact that everyone chose to wear a mask at the end reveals that majority of the people were against Norsefire, which in turn creates the impression that the people are more powerful as a whole. By having V by himself wearing the mask, left him alienated from majority of people. This thereby expressed that he was the only one—or one of the minority—who felt this way about fascism. By having him alienated, emphasizes how powerless he is towards his cause. However, with the incorporation of everyone wearing a mask, emphasizes that he is not alone, thereby bringing power to the people. Along with this, the concept of all the citizens wearing masks lessens the significance of V's identity, and more of the concept of V.

Overall, though there may be several variances between the graphic novel and the film, both are very anticipating and immersed with symbols and allusions.

James McTeigue's political action thriller V for Vendetta (2005) is a phenomenal masterpiece adapting Alan Moore and David Lloyd's graphic novel of the same name. You will be engaged by the creative action choreography, cool visuals, and absorbing performances. V for Vendetta forces you to ask yourself what you think of your own government and responsibilities as a citizen with rights. V for Vendetta is one of the coolest and most memorable pictures I have ever had the pleasure of watching. Do yourself a favor and give V for Vendetta and Moore's revolutionary ideas a chance. I'm sure you will enjoy it and one day appreciate its deeper ideas.

Natalie Portman is devastating as the likable and sympathetic young revolutionary Evey Hammond. Her shaved head is striking, but it's her hurt eyes, shaking body, and tender voice that captivate just as much as her lovely looks. Portman is an outstanding actress and V for Vendetta is one of her best roles alongside Leon the Professional, Black Swan, and Jackie. She has sincere chemistry with Hugo Weaving's mysterious and majestic V. 

Weaving's commanding body language and deep voice give V the gravitas and presence necessary for V for Vendetta to be so powerful a picture. Weaving delivers monologue after monologue, joke after joke, slash after slash, explosion after explosion, and mesmerizes you entirely throughout V for Vendetta. Hugo Weaving gives us one of cinema's most magical performances just with his expressive body language and vulnerable voice. Weaving is certainly one of the greatest actors who ever lived.

Stephen Rea is compelling as Chief Inspector Eric Finch. His face rumbles over each clue and gives each piece of information meaning. He's a fantastic stand in for the audience slowly uncovering the dread truth of V for Vendetta's secrets. Rupert Graves is excellent as his observant and steadfast partner Dominic. Stephen Fry is funny as the television comedian host Gordon Deitrich with his natural charm and silly persona of whimsy. Tim Pigott-Smith is perfectly stern as the cruel SS parallel Creedy. 

Natasha Wightman is peerless as the lesbian lover Valerie Page in the moving montage in the middle of V for Vendetta. Imogen Poots is wonderful as a young Valerie Page. Eddie Marsan is fun as the cowardly sycophant Etheridge. Roger Allam is disgusting as the vile conservative reporter Lewis Prothero. Ben Miles' Dascomb fits the ever loyal media leader following the government's every word aptly. Lastly for the cast, Sinead Cusack is great and touching as Dr. Delia Surridge.

McTeigue's masterful direction is completely enthralling as you are thrust into a moving story that parallels real life crimes against humanity carried out by Adolf Hitler, Margaret Thatcher, and Donald Trump's tyrannical conservative administrations. The concentration camp comparisons and lesbian life story told in the middle of V for Vendetta are as brilliant visual storytelling as any director has captured. He tells Moore's important and influential story about how fascism can rise to power after tragedy through a vulnerable and angry general population grown complacent to atrocity. Moore significantly shows how a government controlling the media, military, and police can censor all with propaganda and control the public with fear and violence. 

Lilly and Lana Wachowski brilliantly adapt Alan Moore's original words for the silver screen with a deft understanding of how he desired to demonstrate how anarchy can combat fascism in England and elsewhere. It's a shame Moore doesn't like this adaption because V for Vendetta remains one of the most striking films you'll ever see.

Moore's writing is visceral, intelligent, researched, compelling, thoughtful, and timeless as we've sadly seen dictator after dictator come to power across the globe in similar fashion to Sir John Hurt's Chancellor Adam Sutler. Rest in peace to one of humanity's greatest actors as Hurt intensely commands your attention as the ferocious and raging authoritarian leading the hateful, racist, Norsefire political party that parallels modern day Republicans far too close for comfort. Hate breeds hate and V for Vendetta teaches us that only the brave citizens willing to die to stand up to evil powers can snuff out such hate-mongering flames.

Martin Walsh's editing is slick with clever cuts to similar looking characters, expressive montages, and harsh cuts during action all for a smooth and hypnotic feel to V for Vendetta. It's a solid 132 minutes, but feels half that length. Adrian Biddle's cinematography keeps faces zoomed in and action as wide as possible for a stunning dichotomy. Owen Paterson's production design looks futuristic in as realistic a way as possible for this dystopian London. All the black and red set decoration is striking and unforgettable. The knife trail special effects are timeless and as cool as anything physical combat sequences ever filmed.

Dario Marianelli and Benjamin Wallfisch's score is mesmerizing. All the classical compositions are nice choices for inspiring a beautiful political revolution. I adore Natalie Portman's shaved head haircut and V's Guy Fawkes' mask. His all black cloak and armor make him appear like a shadow or an idea of a superhero for the masses that we so desperately need. In all, I suppose we'll all have to act, vote, and organize every election to keep authority in check.

Alan Moore's V for Vendetta is a literary classic that sheds light on the hypothetical injustices in modern London. The story is set in the late 2020s and draws many parallels to the present day between the way the government was portrayed, the media's depiction of the events occurring, and the way people didn't question any of it until someone brought an idea to light. Whether you love or hate this film, you can't change the fact that the script/dialogue and casting are ingenious or that the themes are influential. 

V for Vendetta depicts a modern London under the rule of a fascist Chancellor Sutler. Throughout the movie, V, played by Hugo Weaving, is seen as a controlling hand that changes London for everyone around him. V is protective of Evey Hammond, played by Natalie Portman, from the very beginning of the film. Everything he does seems to be to help someone else. He begins by protecting Evey from others, so she returns the favor. He tries throughout the movie to help her see his perspective. They help each other throughout the movie to see the world in a new light. V helps Evey to see the truth about the fascist government and what they were trying to keep hidden as well as his reasoning for his actions throughout the movie. Evey gives V the chance to learn to love again. 

A crucial detail that makes a movie what it is is the script and the dialogue between characters along with the characters themselves. V for Vendetta did not disappoint in this aspect. With lines that are delivered beautifully by the actors and actresses, the script packs a powerful punch. The script, dialogue, and casting all come together to get the theme of freedom across. 

It could be argued that this movie is a bit of a controversy. While it was good, certain details can't be overlooked. For example, V and his ability to completely take over British television. Since the movie is set in a futuristic time and a fascist England, you would think that national broadcasting would have plenty of security and be difficult to hack. However, V makes it seem simple and can broadcast with no issues. Another example is how easy it was for V to send mass mail packaging; I'm talking hundreds of thousands of items delivered to the people in London. Those details along with the fact that this movie encourages government overthrowing make it a bit of a controversy. 

The story depicted in this movie is both heartfelt and eye-opening. The lack of romance between the characters allows the story to progress without interruption or distraction from the plot. V for Vendetta reveals the dangers of discrimination and hate towards others as well as the impacts of authoritarian rule.

V is exceedingly well-spoken. V is a man who wants tyranny to end and uses eloquent language, at times, with alliteration to make his point. The movie begins with, in my opinion, the best quote of the movie. "Voilà! In view, a humble vaudevillian veteran, cast vicariously as both victim and villain by the vicissitudes of Fate. This visage, no mere veneer of vanity, is a vestige of the vox populi, now vacant, vanished. However, this valorous visitation of a by-gone vexation, stands vivified and has vowed to vanquish these venal and virulent vermin vanguarding vice and vouchsafing the violently vicious and voracious violation of volition. Verily, this vichyssoise of verbiage veers most verbose, so let me simply add that it's my very good honor to meet you and you may call me V." He literally describes the entire movie in one long passage full of alliteration; essentially, V is saying that he is neither villain nor victim but is seen as both. What upsets me is that people seem to forget that this is just a comic book movie and that it's even very faithful to the 1989 graphic novel, but people weren't so aggressive on the graphic novel because it came out in time that the internet wasn't such a big deal, but when the movie came out, which wasn't that very much different of the graphic novel, they were so aggressively criticizing it, just like what happened with the 2019 Todd Phillips' Joker, which is very sad because people don't look at the movie as a whole and get what it's trying to tell us or show us, they just look at one minor thing and they just sit down and trash it!

This movie is NOT encouraging terrorism, it's encouraging our demands for freedom, and to take what authority is taking from its people, in the form of a "terrorist", though I don't like to call him that!

Now let's talk about the movie itself.

First of all, what's so hard to neglect, the performances! Everyone in this movie did an amazing job, especially Hugo Weaving who was wearing a mask for the whole runtime, and still we could see and feel every emotion and every reaction and his face, he delivered an amazing character without even seeing his face! And that was great, I liked that for the whole movie we didn't get to see his face at all and that even when he took off his mask in one scene his face was so shadowy that we couldn't see it, that shows that, as he said, the mask is now his face and not the one beneath.

Natalie Portman is also great in this movie, everyone is great in this movie, there isn't one bad performance or even a character that was badly built, everyone was great!

The plot is very intriguing, it's very easy to start this movie not that interested, and within a couple of minutes you just get very hooked, and that's where McTeigue shines, he built this atmosphere, and this futuristic world in a way that can keep you very intrigued in no time! The plot is so smart, and the movie can help it but to get even better with each scene, the movie is always going up intensely and smartly, it never loses its mystique nor its heart!

What McTeigue has done amazingly was the editing, though it didn't always work, and we'll get to that later, for the most part, the editing is what makes this movie very good to look at, because visually, and I don't mean special effects, this movie is just beautiful! That shows in a lot of scenes, for instance, the scene where Evey was on the rooftop, and she was walking under the rain, feeling like she's being reborn, and the shots where V was coming out of the fire, feeling like he's being reborn as well, were merged in a way that makes this scene beyond perfect!

The screenplay is also very well-written, every line was well-crafted, smart dialogue that makes this movie amazing and intriguing.

You know a great movie when you look at the main characters at the beginning of the movie, and then you check them out again at the end of it and you see how different they are, and how good they were developed, this movie has one of the best characters development in comic book movies! You take a look at Evey's character and you see her at the beginning, a very simple and nice girl, who's not that brave but still trying to protect herself, you see her at the end, and I don't wanna get into spoilers, and you just can't believe that this is her, she took her time to be "reborn" and that made the audience care about her very much. The same happened with a lot of characters, and a lot of characters you look at them thinking that they're not that important, or you think of them that they're those a-holes, but when you get to know their secrets or their backstories you just can't help it but to love them as well!

Some people will go to watch this movie expecting a ton of action sequences like The Matrix, even the trailer showed us that this movie is gonna have a lot of action sequences, but no, this movie doesn't have a lot of that, and a lot of people will get disappointed, but for me, I don't care, the movie has a couple of that, and that was enough for me, it's the drama and the thriller that intrigued me and made me entertained, so here's the thing, don't go to this movie expecting The Matrix, it has a couple of action sequences, but that's about it, this movie is a crime, drama, and thriller.

This movie is not by any means perfect, it has a couple of flaws, and what bothered me was some of the editings, I know I said is that this is where McTeigue shines, but some of it just didn't work, for example, there's a scene with V and Evey watching the TV, and the news of the death of a certain character is being broadcasted, she asks him if he's behind this, and he confirms it, she asks him if he's gonna do it again, and he says "yes" and the scene ends, for me, it felt unfinished, I thought that there will be more, some kind of a conversation about why he thinks to kill is the answer, but there wasn't, and that happened often in this movie.

What I also didn't like was the exposition scenes, it happened more often, it wasn't badly made or anything, but it was frequently used, and it didn't work for me because the movie seemed smarter than this to me.

In the end, V for Vendetta is a great comic book movie, if you liked the graphic novel, I don't see why would you hate this movie, just forget what everyone's saying about this movie, and go see it for yourself. I'm gonna give V for Vendetta an A-!

Watch it without interruptions, without distractions and erase all preconceived notions about it. Have a willingness to see yourself in not only the main characters, but in the people and the symbolism throughout. 

Every single character represents a part the human heart within all of us:

The frightened young woman who is just trying to keep her head down and get by suddenly being thrown against her will into a whirlwind of events that change her life and her destiny forever. 

The masked enigma, a man who does have an identity but chooses to convey a different one in order to send a message to his people, a man who is willing to lay down his life for what he loves and believes in most. V is a human being who endured some of the most heinous acts against him, and it transformed him into a fluid entity, as much a symbol to his people as he is a living, breathing flesh and blood man. A man who hurts, who hates, who loves, and a man who can die.

The masses, so focused on group-think and blending in so as not to arouse government suspicions for being a separatist or radical. Or the child, in all the innocence of youth and a representation of anyone's son or daughter, becoming the catalyst needed to finally make the light bulb turn on in the people's heads.

In 2027, the world is in turmoil and warfare, with the United States fractured as a result of prolonged second civil war and a pandemic of the "St. Mary's Virus" ravaging Europe. The United Kingdom is ruled as a fascist police state by the Norsefire Party, helmed by all-powerful High Chancellor Adam Sutler (John Hurt). Political opponents, immigrants, Jews, Muslims, atheists, homosexuals, and other "undesirables" are imprisoned and executed in concentration camps. On November 4, a vigilante in a Guy Fawkes mask identifying himself as "V" (Hugo Weaving) rescues Evey Hammond (Natalie Portman), an employee of the state-run British Television Network, from members of the "Fingermen" secret police while she is out past curfew. From a rooftop, they watch his demolition of London's main criminal court, the Old Bailey, accompanied by fireworks and the "1812 Overture". Inspector Finch (Stephen Rea) of Scotland Yard is asked to investigate V's activities while BTN declares the incident an "emergency demolition". V interrupts the broadcast to claim responsibility, encouraging the people of Britain to rise up against their government and meet him on next year's Guy Fawkes Night outside the Houses of Parliament. During the broadcast, the police attempt to capture V. Evey helps him escape, but is knocked unconscious. V takes Evey to his home, where she is told she must remain for one year. V then kills Lewis Prothero, Norsefire's chief propagandist, and Anthony Lilliman, the Bishop of London. Evey offers to help, and uses the opportunity to escape to the home of her boss, comedian and talk show host Gordon Deitrich (Stephen Fry). In return for Evey trusting him with her safety, Gordon reveals prohibited materials, including subversive paintings, an antique Quran, and homoerotic photographs. Meanwhile, V confronts Dr. Delia Surridge, who had experimented on him and many other "undesirables" 20 years ago at Larkhill concentration camp; seeing her remorse for her past actions, he kills her painlessly. After Gordon performs a satire of the government on his show, his home is raided and Evey is captured. She is imprisoned and tortured for information about V, with her only solace being a note written by actress Valerie Page, a former prisoner who was tortured and killed for her lesbianism. Evey is told she will be executed unless she reveals V's location. When she says she would rather die, she is inexplicably released, and then finds herself in V's home. It turns out that V was the one who had "captured" her at Gordon's home, and staged her imprisonment and torture to free her from her fears. The note was real, passed from Valerie to V when he was imprisoned. He also informs her that Deitrich had been executed when the Quran was found in his home. While Evey initially hates V for what he did to her, she realises she has become a stronger person. She leaves him, promising to return before November 5. Reading the deceased Surridge's journal, Finch learns V is the result of human experimentation and has been targeting the people who detained him. Despite being stonewalled by the government, Finch searches for the true identity of V, tracing him to a bioweapons program in Larkhill. Finch meets William Rookwood, who tells him that the program, which was directed by Sutler (who was then Undersecretary of Defence), resulted in the creation of the deadly St. Mary's Virus. He further reveals that Creedy, a leader of the Norsefire Party, released the virus onto English soil, killing 100,000 British residents and framing the outbreak as an attack by a terrorist organisation. The Party, which promised security in times of social instability, used the ensuing wave of fear to elevate Sutler to the newly created office of High Chancellor and win an overwhelming majority in Parliament, becoming the elected government. Finch later discovers the man he met was V in disguise, and though he initially disbelieves the story, his faith in the Norsefire government is severely shaken. As November 5 nears, V distributes thousands of Guy Fawkes masks, and the population questions party rule as the nation slowly descends into anarchy, ignited when one of the Fingermen makes the mistake of shooting and killing a young girl committing vandalism, only to be killed in turn by a mob of enraged citizens. On the eve of November 5, Evey visits V, who shows her an explosive-laden train in the abandoned London Underground, set to destroy Parliament. He leaves it to Evey to decide whether to use it...

Ebert and Roeper gave the film a "two thumbs up" rating. Roger Ebert stated that V for Vendetta "almost always has something going on that is actually interesting, inviting us to decode the character and plot and apply the message where we will". Margaret Pomeranz and David Stratton from At the Movies stated that despite the problem of never seeing Weaving's face, there was good acting and an interesting plot, adding that the film is also disturbing, with scenes reminiscent of Nazi Germany. Jonathan Ross from the BBC blasted the film, calling it a "woeful, depressing failure" and stating that the "cast of notable and familiar talents such as John Hurt and Stephen Rea stand little chance amid the wreckage of the Wachowski siblings' dismal script and its particularly poor dialogue." Sean Burns of Philadelphia Weekly gave the film a 'D', criticizing the film's treatment of its political message as being "fairly dim, adolescent stuff," as well as expressing dislike for the "barely decorated sets with television-standard overlit shadow-free cinematography by the late Adrian Biddle. On Alan Moore removing his name from the project, Burns says "it's not hard to see why," as well as criticising Portman's performance: "Portman still seems to believe that standing around with your mouth hanging open constitutes a performance." Harry Guerin from the Irish TV network RTÉ states the film "works as a political thriller, adventure and social commentary and it deserves to be seen by audiences who would otherwise avoid any/all of the three". Trivia: The original comic series was originally created by Alan Moore. However, following his negative experience with From Hell (2001) and The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen (2003), Moore decided to reject all money and credit from Hollywood on any adaptations of his work. Thus, he gave all the money he would've gotten to the artist who drew the character with him, and rejected his own "created by" credit from the film.

V wears a mask in the guise of Guy Fawkes, who is most famous for his involvement in the Gunpowder Plot of 1605, which he was placed in charge of executing, due to his military and explosives experience. The plot, masterminded by Robert Catesby, was a failed attempt by a group of provincial English Roman Catholic conspirators to kill King James I of England (the Sixth of Scotland), his family, and most of the Protestant aristocracy in one swoop, by blowing up the Houses of Parliament during its State Opening.

Alan Moore, writer of the original graphic novel, greatly disliked the film, criticizing the script for "having plot holes you wouldn't have gotten away with on Wizzer and Chips in the 1960s". He ended cooperation with his publisher, DC Comics, after its corporate parent, Warner Brothers, failed to retract statements about Moore's supposed endorsement of the film. Joel Silver said at a press conference that Lana Wachowski had talked with Moore, and that "Moore was very excited about what Lana had to say." Moore disputed this, reporting that he told Wachowski "I didn't want anything to do with films. I wasn't interested in Hollywood," and demanded that DC Comics force Warner Brothers to issue a public retraction and apology for Silver's "blatant lies". Although Silver called Moore directly to apologize, no public retraction appeared. Moore was quoted as saying that the comic book had been "specifically about things like fascism and anarchy. The words 'fascism' and 'anarchy' occur nowhere in the film. It's been turned into a Bush-era parable by people too timid to set a political satire in their own country." This conflict between Moore and DC Comics was the subject of an article in The New York Times on March 12, 2006, five days before the U.S. release. In the New York Times article, Silver stated that about twenty years prior to the film's release, he met with Moore and David Gibbons when Silver acquired the film rights to V For Vendetta and Watchmen. Silver stated: "Alan was odd, but he was enthusiastic and encouraging us to do this. I had foolishly thought that he would continue feeling that way today, not realizing that he wouldn't." Moore did not deny this meeting, nor Silver's characterization of Moore at that meeting, nor did Moore state that he advised Silver of his change of opinion in those approximately twenty years. The New York Times article also interviewed David Lloyd about Moore's reaction to the film's production, stating, "Mr. Lloyd, the illustrator of V for Vendetta, also found it difficult to sympathize with Mr. Moore's protests. When he and Mr. Moore sold their film rights to the comic book, Mr. Lloyd said: "We didn't do it innocently. Neither myself nor Alan thought we were signing it over to a board of trustees who would look after it like it was the Dead Sea Scrolls."

V for Vendetta is the directorial debut of James McTeigue, and it stars Hugo Weaving, Natalie Portman, Stephen Rea, and John Hurt in a dystopian political thriller that is based on the same comic book by David Lloyd and Alan Moore about   England being under command of its ruler in the distant future, and when Evey Hammond (Natalie Portman) almost got attacked by some people, a vigilante that wears a Guy Fawkes mask saves her, and kept her for a while as other people will start looking for her also, which she starts to figure more about his plan before November 5th has come in. When I first watched this film years ago, all I remember from it is that it has one of the best writing that I've seen in a film in years, so it was something to look forward to when seeing it again, and to my surprise, V for Vendetta turned out to be one of my favorite films. Hugo Weaving is amazing in this that you can only hear his voice and not see his face, and he's very intimidating even with the mask on. Natalie Portman is great as she usually is, and when she has to act like she lost her feeling of her emotions, it's better acted than I saw from Will Smith or Jaden Smith in After Earth. Stephen Rea does a good job of acting monotonous, and John Hurt is really good as the villain as I never seen him play that type of character. The characters are very three-dimensional, even with the subtle backstories from V whom we still don't know his identity, but wouldn't care about it as the characters are a lot of fun to watch. The writing by The Wachowski Brothers is at it's A game as the lines are clever, it tells some Bible quotes that are related to this story, and it's clever that when you think it'll lead this way, it goes to a different direction that surprised me. Even if there's a lot of exposition as The Wachowski Brothers usually write their films that way, but it's done in a well executed way that I didn't care. The political allegory is really clever, and it gives in to a lot of thought-provoking moments that gets people to think differently after watching this film. The action scenes are entertaining to watch, and the effects look really good with the explosions, and the setting that it takes place as it's a bit different in a way that takes place in the nearest future. V for Vendetta is a masterpiece for me that I understand why people still wears a Guy Fawkes mask to represent V for what he stand out for.

On the one hand, a blockbuster action movie even attempting to make a statement on modern democracy (the references to the Bush administration and the Nazis are all but subtle) is laudable, and the film has its strengths- Weaving, Rea and Fry are great in their roles, the editing and story flow are fast, but never overwhelming, and some scenes like the domino montage are genuinely chilling. However, ultimately, V For Vendetta falls into mediocrity with its many, MANY plot holes (often deriving from the changes to the source material), its lackluster set design and, most importantly, in how unreflected, black-and-white and yet confused its message is. V is a hero in everything he does, his killings of nameless men in police suits or cartoon villains are glorified, so is the psychological torture of Evey, and that is never questioned. The film is sending a message on the power of ideas and the people while not allowing the audience to have their own ideas about the proceedings (again, V is a hero and the goverment are all but called Nazis, John Hurt's absurdly over-the-top performance doesn't help either) and stating that Norsefire manipulated the people in the movie, granting them amnesty from them electing Norsefire in the first place. The goverment SHOULD be scared of their people, but how can they be if you don't make them think for themselves and blindly follow symbols and icons.

"V for Vendetta" is a story about revenge. Simple enough, but it also contains some thoughts I'd dare call profound, along with solid performances and several iconic moments that will stick with you. Is it a faithful adaptation of the graphic novel by Alan Moore? Not really, but like any interpretation or adaptation, it's ok to deviate from the source material as long as the end result is good and the spirit remains. It's not like this movie is going to barge into your house and burn every copy of the comic after all.

Set in an Orwellian-like England, Evey (Natalie Portman) happens upon an extraordinary man, a masked vigilante simply known as V (voiced by Hugo Weaving). Think of V as a cross between Edmund Dantes (from "The Count of Monte Cristo", you uncultured swine!) and Batman. Is he a terrorist, or the savior the country has been silently praying for? Either way he's out for blood and seeking to take down the totalitarian government, partially because it ties into his own mysterious past. 

Based on the graphic novel written by Alan Moore and illustrated by David Lloyd, this 2006 release but varies wildly from the pages that originally brought the characters to life. I'm torn to which I like better. Here, V is seen as a heroic vigilante and less like a wildfire spawned from the discontent of the masses. Other changes set the story in more contemporary times and there is less emphasis on the tyrannical government. The amount of characters is significantly reduced and most of the sub-plots are gone, replaced with more backstory on the world. It makes for a product that's significantly less intellectual and more action-oriented, but there is still a pretty solid brain rattling in that Guy Fawkes mask.

What works best is that viewing the picture feels empowering, even while never leaving the real of complete fantasy. V is a charismatic hero that makes the whole rebellion thing look easy. He's such a larger-than-life character that he transcends the limitations of the media and goes on to inspire rebellion and power to the audience with his eloquent speeches, incredibly intricate plots and moments of kick-ass kung-Fu. The 17th-century conical hat, the black outfit (cape, gloves, tunic, trousers and boots) and the "face" with the shoulder-length wig of straight hair and the Guy Fawkes mask are incredibly iconic. It's that right mix of theatrics and realism. With the film's big climax, set a on the 5th of November no one is ever likely to forget... it's no wonder that visage has become a symbol for disgruntled youths looking to rebel.

There are numerous bits of dialogue that will stick with you and shake you out of your sluggish existence, lines like "Ideas are bulletproof" and "There are no coincidences, only the illusion of coincidences" and probably most iconic of all "People should not be afraid of their government, government should be afraid of their people".  Those are my personal favorites. There is a long speech where V introduces himself so eloquently phrased it makes you want to pause the scene and rewind it over and over until you've memorized it.
 
V is a character you are instantly drawn to and want to learn more about, but he's not the only compelling player. We've got an avatar for the audience, a sidekick to our superhero in the form of Evey. She's got plenty going in both in the way she interacts with V and how she transforms over the course of the plot. The two characters have an interesting relationship that switches between hero & damsel in distress, aggressor & victim, mentor & pupil, lost soul & savior and there's a hint of romance thrown in. These characters begin on not necessarily opposite sides, but on very different planes of thinking. As their interactions are shown on screen, you will flip between whom you associate with more closely. While some of the in-depth sub plots from the novel are gone, I feel like the ones that remain keep the film afloat. 

The action is memorable and well shot, particularly during the sequences when V gets to really show off him karate gimmicks against a slew of opponents. There are several big explosions throughout the movie, nerve-wracking turns, tense decisions made, and all balanced with some moments of deep reflection/contemplation. A particular highlight in the set design is V's lair, which is reminiscent of a museum and an antique store in desperate need of a serious clearance sale, but quite striking. You'll find a ton of theatrics and moments that will have you pumped, excited to see more.

When it's all over, you might even have learned a thing about how you ultimately feel about revenge. If not, hey at least you saw a blood-pumping action movie about not taking no guff from nobody. There's a lot of re-watch value contained in the 132 minute running time and you're going to praise the Home Video Gods when you realize turning on the subtitles makes it a whole lot easier to memorize the epic speeches delivered throughout. I find myself itching to watch "V For Vendetta" every 5th of November, if only so I can pretend like I can recite every line and sound as majestic as Hugo Weaving, or capture a sliver of the work that inspired the film.
